title: 103_hr1284
content:
The "Independent Counsel Act of 1993" extends the term from five to eleven years in Section 599 of title 28, United States Code. It also applies to members of Congress. SEC. 3. APPLICATION TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS: Amends Section 591(b) of title 28, United States Code to include Senators, Representatives, Delegates, and Resident Commissioners within the scope of the Act. SEC. 4. PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include a provision for the periodic reappointment of independent counsel. If an independent counsel has not been terminated within two years of their original appointment or at the end of each succeeding 2-year period, they must apply for reappointment. The court will assess whether the counsel's office should be terminated and if not, the counsel may be reappointed or replaced by another qualified individual. The court must take action within 90 days if an independent counsel has not been terminated within the 2-year period. If no action is taken, the office of the independent counsel will terminate after the 90-day period. SEC. 5. PERIODIC REPORTS.

Section 595(a)(2) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to require independent counsels to annually report on their activities, including progress on investigations or prosecutions. The report must justify expenditures and provide general information on the state of their work.

SEC. 6. EFFECT OF TERMINATION OF CHAPTER.

Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify that the office of an independent counsel will terminate either upon completion of their duties or after 120 days, whichever comes first.

SEC. 7. SUBPOENA POWER. SEC. 7. SUBPOENA POWER.

Section 592(a)(2) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow the issuance of subpoenas duces tecum. 

SEC. 8. CONGRESSIONAL REQUESTS.

Section 592(g)(2) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include requests related to possible violations of law described in section 591(a) by individuals in section 591(b).

SEC. 9. ATTORNEY'S FEES.

Section 593(f)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to remove language related to indictments and investigations. SEC. 10. INDEPENDENT COUNSEL PER DIEM EXPENSES. Section 594(b) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to adjust compensation for independent counsels. An independent counsel appointed under this chapter shall receive compensation at the per diem rate equal to the annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel and lodging expenses in Washington, D.C. are restricted after 1 year of service. SEC. 11. RESTRICTIONS ON STAFF. Section 594(c) of title 28, United States Code is amended to limit salaries for employees of independent counsels to levels comparable to those in the office of the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia. Independent counsels are encouraged to use Department of Justice personnel and are restricted to spending no more than $500,000 per year on appointed or detailed employees. The salaries for employees of independent counsels are limited to levels comparable to those in the office of the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia. Independent counsels are encouraged to use Department of Justice personnel and are restricted to spending no more than $500,000 per year on appointed or detailed employees, except when additional funds are made available by an appropriations Act. SEC. 12 amends Section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code to ensure compliance with Department of Justice policies. SEC. 13 grants enforcement authority to the Department of Justice and the Office of Government Ethics for ethics enforcement. SEC. 14 imposes restrictions on expenditures. SEC. 14 imposes restrictions on expenditures for independent counsel offices, limiting funds after a 2-year period unless specified in later appropriations Acts. Section 594 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include administrative and cost controls for independent counsels. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts will provide support and office space, while independent counsels must manage expenses and authorize reasonable expenditures. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts will provide support and office space for independent counsels, who must manage expenses in accordance with specified principles. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act, with recommendations to improve cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
